intro: Mapaniopsis micrococca, commonly known as the small white globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its small, white or pale pink flowers bloom in late spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The leaves are palmately lobed, providing a distinctive appearance that aids in its identification.
